facts.text: Appellant R.R. Chari was permanent employee in gazetted post under Government of Assam; services lent to Government of India in 1941.

Appellant held positions: Deputy Director of Metals in Munitions Production Department at Calcutta, then Delhi office of Master-General of Ordnance, transferred to Kanpur as Assistant Iron & Steel Controller in 1945, Deputy Iron & Steel Controller Kanpur Circle from September 1945 briefly, then from January 1946 to September 20, 1946.
Charges relate to period January 1, 1946 to September 20, 1946; appellant proceeded on leave for four months on September 20, 1946 and did not return.

Government of India wrote to Assam Government on February 8, 1947, to revert services on expiry of leave from September 21, 1946; leave gazetted April 28, 1947 for four months; extended to May 13, 1947.
Appellant suspended by Central Government on May 13, 1947; arrested on warrant October 28, 1947; released on bail.
Sanction for prosecution under s.197 CrPC accorded by Government of India on January 31, 1949.
Charge-sheet alleged conspiracy, corruption, forgery by appellant with Vaish (clerk), Rizwi and Rawat (clerks); Rizwi absconded to Pakistan, Rawat died; trial against appellant and Vaish.

Prosecution case: Conspiracy under s.120B IPC to commit offences under ss.161,165,467 IPC or r.47(3) r/w r.47(2) Defence of India Rules 1939, abetment in contravention of Iron & Steel Control of Distribution Order 1941.
Second charge: s.161 IPC (bribes from 14 persons) or alternatively s.165 IPC.
Third charge: s.467 IPC or alternatively r.47(3) r/w r.47(2)(a) Defence of India Rules; 14 forged documents including orders and licences.
Fourth charge: Abetment of offences under r.81(2) Defence of India Rules by specified firms.
Preliminary objection to sanction validity rejected by Harish Chandra J., Allahabad HC on July 18, 1949.
Trial by Additional District & Sessions Judge, Kanpur on May 7, 1953: s.120B with assessors, others with jury.

Trial court convicted appellant under s.120B (2 years RI), s.161 (2 years RI + Rs.25,000 fine), s.467 (4 years RI), r.81(4) r/w r.121 Defence of India Rules & Iron Steel Order clauses (2 years RI); all concurrent. Vaish also convicted.

Allahabad HC appeal: Accepted misdirections to jury, examined evidence itself; rejected 8/10 instances, accepted 2: Lala Sheo Karan Das (Rs.4,000 on 31.3.1946, Rs.2,000 on 9.4.1946, Rs.1,060 on 11.4.1946, Rs.1,000 on 12.5.1946; forged docs P-341, P-342) and Sher Singh Arora (furniture: sofa set, centre piece, stools, chair in Jan 1946; forged P-535, P-294). Confirmed conviction under ss.161 & 467; set aside s.120B & r.81(4); concurrent sentences. Vaish acquitted.
Certificate granted by HC; appeal to SC.
Sheo Karan Das case: Bribes for orders P-341, P-342 ante-dated; licences ante-dated; corroborated by kachhi rokar books, son Bhola Nath, nephew Parshotam Das; quota register tampered.
Sher Singh Arora case: Accepted furniture (Exts.16-21) Jan 1946; licences P-535, P-294 ante-dated; quota register tampered.
Commitment order passed March 1, 1952; Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 came into force July 28, 1952; Special Judge appointed September 18, 1952; case not transferred as post-commitment.
Appellant cooperated with Kanhaiya Singh (Income-tax) against black-marketeers; burglaries, fire at their houses.
Appellant left Kanpur March 23, 1946 for Calcutta meeting with Mr. Spooner (no licences after March 26); returned March 28, issued licences dated March 23 even on later applications till March 31.
Assam Government had no desire for reversion until criminal proceedings over; appellant sought LPR.

legal_issues.text: Whether Additional District Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to try the case post Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952, or only Special Judge.
Validity of sanction under s.197 CrPC: whether granted by Governor-General exercising individual judgment; whether appellant employed under Federation or Assam at time of sanction.
Validity of sanction under s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 for offences under ss.161/165 IPC, given loaned servant from Assam to Centre.
Sufficiency of evidence for conviction under s.467 IPC / alternative Defence of India Rules charges, based on uncorroborated accomplice testimony re ante-dating.

petitioner_arguments.text: Addl. Sessions Judge lacked jurisdiction post Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952; case pending before committing Magistrate despite commitment order due to s.219 CrPC powers.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 ss.7,10; CrPC s.219

petitioner_arguments.text: Sanction under s.197 CrPC invalid: not showing Governor-General's individual judgment; appellant reverted to Assam service.
Under Prevention of Corruption Act s.6, as loaned servant permanently employed by Assam, sanction required from Assam Provincial Government (cl.(c)), not Centre.
Prosecution motivated by black-marketeers; 8/10 instances rejected by HC; evidence for 467 based on uncorroborated accomplices; ante-dating licences non-criminal per Spooner instructions.

respondent_arguments.text: Post-commitment, case not pending before Magistrate under s.10 Criminal Law Amendment Act; trial under CrPC proper.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Criminal Law Amendment Act ss.7,10; CrPC ss.213,215,219

respondent_arguments.text: Sanction valid under s.197; appellant employed under Federation at sanction time; no reversion order.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.197; Afzelur Rahman v. King Emperor

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant changed procedures to deal directly with black-marketeers; fled Kanpur fearing investigation.
Retrial under s.161 warranted if sanction obtained.

court_reasoning.text: Commitment order ended Magistrate's jurisdiction; s.219 supplementary power does not mean case pending before Magistrate under s.10 Criminal Law Amendment Act; Addl. Sessions Judge had jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cases post-commitment not transferred to Special Judge.

court_reasoning.text: Sanction under s.197 valid: detailed, prima facie case considered; point of individual judgment not raised earlier; appellant still under Federation employment, no reversion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relevant employment at time of sanction determines authority.

court_reasoning.text: Under Prevention of Corruption Act s.6, 'employed' in cls.(a),(b) means permanently employed; loaned servant falls under cl.(c) - Assam authority required; sanction invalid for ss.161/165.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of s.6 differs from s.197 CrPC.

court_reasoning.text: For s.467: No independent evidence of ante-dating applications (no receipt register); quota tampering source unknown; appellant's admission explained by Spooner instructions (valid till 31.3); uncorroborated accomplices insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Crucial fact of application dates proved only by accomplices without corroboration.

court_reasoning.text: No retrial for s.161: protracted trial over 14 years; reduced to 2 accomplice instances.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ends of justice do not require fresh trial.

holdings.text: Sanction under s.6 Prevention of Corruption Act invalid for ss.161/165; proceedings without jurisdiction.
Evidence insufficient for s.467/alternative charges; uncorroborated accomplice testimony.

precedents_cited.case_name: Afzelur Rahman v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of s.197 CrPC to protect public servants from frivolous prosecution.
Madras HC: Special Judge no jurisdiction if commitment pre-Act.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Previous sanction for ss.161/165 IPC; authority based on permanent employment.

statutes_cited.name: Iron and Steel (Control of Distribution) Order, 1941
Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Special Judge jurisdiction for s.161 etc.; transfer of pending cases.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside convictions under ss.161, 467 IPC and alternative charges; acquitted and discharged appellant on all counts due to invalid sanction under Prevention of Corruption Act s.6 for bribery charges and insufficient uncorroborated evidence for forgery; no retrial ordered considering protracted proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal and discharge on all charges

key_quotes.text: The object of s.197(1) clearly is to save public servants from frivolous prosecution.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Having regard to the scheme of the three clauses of s.6, it is difficult to construe the word 'employed' in cls.(a),(b) as meaning employed for the time being. The said words...must mean permanently employed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes s.6 PCA from s.197 CrPC; basis for invalid sanction.

key_quotes.text: The crucial fact on which the charge under s.467 is based is deposed to only by accomplice witnesses and their statements are not corroborated by any other evidence on the record.
key_quotes.speaker: court
